activity.description: Climate change is a continuous phenomenon and it is difficult to quantify its future impacts. There is an urgent need for methods and tools that enable us to make a reasonable assessment of both the present and future impacts of climate change. It is, therefore, imperative to develop and test these tools. Dynamic crop models are now useful tools to create and analyse the impacts of different climate change scenarios and develop policy foresights.

activity.description: Carrying out improvement of models and simulation runs for long-term changes in CIAT commodities. This work involves global modelling of common bean with DSSAT, modelling of rice in Latin America with DSSAT-ORYZA, and global modelling of cassava. In the case of cassava, significant investment is being made in upgrading the model in DSSAT. This upgrading includes collation of new trial data for calibration, re-programming of the DSSAT model, and release of a new cassava model expected for 2013. For rice, Latin American cultivars are being calibrated through field experimentation as the current version of ORYZA does not have appropriate varieties for LAC.

activity.title: Cost Effectivenes Analysis and Cost-benefit analysis of mitigation/adaptation options for pasture systems, rice, fruits, rubber and soybean in Colombia
activity.description: For mitigation, four subsectors are being analyzed: i) Silvopastoral systems, ii) improved pastures, iii) efficient use of nitrogen fertilizer in rice, and iv) converting degraded pasture to fruits. CIAT is organizing several national workshops to identify regions with major potential to implement silvopstoral systems and improved pasture. In rice, N-Fertilizer dose-response curves are being modeled and inefficient levels of nitrogen fertilizer use identified. Local workshops are being held with producers and local technicians to identify alternatives for improving use-efficiency of N-fertilizer. Regarding fruits, modeling is being used to identify the most suitable locations for growing avocado and mango. Economic information about costs and benefits are being calculated for different locations and a national level MAC Curve is being built. Regarding adaptation, climate change impacts on pasture, rice, soybean and rubber are being estimated and some adaptation measures are being identified by different stakeholders in local workshops. Cost for every measure is being calculated and cost-benefit analyses carried out.

activity.title: Assessing the potential of tropical forage options to mitigate climate change through reducing nitrous oxide emissions and enhancing carbon sequestration
activity.description: The livestock sector accounts for 40% of the total value of global agricultural output and provides livelihoods for nearly 1 billion people. Improved tropical forages could offer the single most effective means to mitigate climate change from agriculture and land use change, while also sustainably boosting production of milk, meat, and crops. Livestock are estimated to be responsible for about half of agriculture's total greenhouse gas emissions. But forages, particularly brachiaria grasses, can offset these emissions through diverse mitigation pathways. These include: (i) carbon sequestration in soil through their deep and abundant root systems, and (ii) reduced emissions of nitrous oxide. Brachiaria grasses suppress nitrification in soil through the release of biological nitrification inhibitors from their roots, an ability known as biological nitrification inhibition (BNI). These inhibitors have the potential to improve recovery of applied nitrogen to crops (e.g., maize) and reduce nitrous oxide emisions from agropastoral systems.

A wide range of data, from different sources, exist on short- and long-terms trials of different management practices in various cropping systems and ecologies. These data, if collated and analysed, could provide important insight into defining suitable recommendation domains.

activity.description: The historical wheat germplasm evaluation database (IWIN) is an unprecedented resource that provides an opportunity to map the adaptation of diverse wheat germplasm - bred explicitly for developiing countries- to a range of climates that span the entire globe over several decades. These data can be used for climate change modelling, impact assessments and defining environmental clines. However, it requires a systematic curation procedure and subsequent analysis such that good quality data can be provided for subsequent studies.

activity.title: Matching of historical maize & wheat germplasm evaluation data with GIS data and current weather data
activity.description: Every year CIMMYT sends promising lines coming out of the breeding pipelines of the global wheat and maize programs to a large number of partners in NARS located globally for wheat and in Africa, Asia and Latin America for maize, each location representing mega environments defined for both crops. The mega environments are utilized by the breeders to plan and target their breeding efforts. Many institutions evaluating these lines send feedback on yields, phenotypic information and pest and disease scorings. This data set, spanning several decades, can be utilized to analyze the impact of climate variability on yield in a large variety of environments. It can be used to calibrate crop models like DSSAT or APSIM over a long period for many different locations worldwide. Information on pests and diseases can be utilized to generate risk maps based on related climate data extracted for the individual locations. For all these purposes, the precision of the locations of the nursery sites has to be as high as possible. A large number of the sites were georeferenced when GPS was not available and thus often inaccurate. This emphasizes the need of the first step in correcting the inaccuracies with current tools and GPS information from nursery site managers. Based on this, creating the analogue layers will enable determination of the areas the nursery sites represent under current climate conditions. Utilizing climate change data sets will allow the identification of those areas that are predicted to have the climate conditions today other maize and wheat growing areas will experience in the future and to identify those areas that are under climate conditions currently that the nursery sites will experience in the future. This will allow the breeders to test new breeding material in such environments and to plan for shifts of climate and mega environments.

activity.title: Suitable international maize trial data identified, collated and relevant climate / environment data of these trials reconstructed or accessed and analysis initiated.
activity.description: The analysis of regional trial datasets generated over a 8-year period in combination with climatic data in southern Africa revealed the vulnerability of maize yields to drought stress under elevated temperatures (Lobell et al. 2011). CIMMYT in collaboration with national partners has also been running regional trials at multiple locations in EA for over 8 years. Compiling this data together with climatic data will provide insight into the performance of maize under different climatic conditions.

activity.title: Discuss usefulness and limitations of carbon footprints in coffee systems based on evidence data compiled across Latin America and quantify total carbon stock in Central American coffee systems.
activity.description: Carbon stocks and footprints vary considerably across coffee agroferestry systems, as do their resultant contributions to climate change and climate change mitigation. On the other hand, they are high carbon storage systems that are not rewarded for the carbon they conserve because the increase in carbon stock per year is minimal. It is important to have evidence data to show the differences between systems and subsequently demonstrate the limitations and potential of carbon footprint measurements.

activity.title: Data compilation to identify coping and adaptation strategies of farmers and the poor to manage future climate outcomes
activity.description: Climate change is threatening the livelihood and food security of many poor farmers in the African continent. The vulnerability of women (both in female- and male-headed households) and men to impacts of climate change are uneven and will be affected differently. Gender-disaggregated data will help us identify and understand the coping and adaptation strategies for climate change used by female and male farmers which in turn will inform gender-sensitive recommendations for coping and adaption strategies to climate variability and extreme events.

activity.title: Analysis and modeling of wheat trial data to identify climate ready traits/ideotypes, and analogue sites in climate vulnerable regions with the medium-term objective of developing phenotyping platforms with NARS collaborators.
activity.description: The first main objective of this activity is to identify the key stress adaptive traits, and combinations of traits, that will be needed to maintain productive wheat crops in warmer regions now and in the future climate scenarios. This will be achieved through analysis and modeling of detailed wheat trial data from heat stressed experimental environments. While conceptual models for adaptation to heat stress have already been developed by CIMMYT, simulation exercises using comprehensive data sets can help determine the levels of expression of traits required to maintain productivity across the range of stress profiles that are likely to be experienced in target sites, as identified by climate models. Clearly, for this information to be applied, experimental sites must be established where germplasm can be evaluated and selected for expression of the appropriate phenotype. Therefore, the second main objective is to develop phenotyping platforms with NARS collaborators so that they can breed for probable climates, e.g. 20 years into the future. While climate models can establish the broad meteorological parameters of future environments, the outputs from crop models will determine which aspects of growth will be most affected. This kind of information can help define the key characteristics of analogue sites since any given analogue site is only an approximation of a range of target environments. For example, it may be that reproductive growth becomes a new bottleneck to productivity, and therefore, it will be crucial that the stress profile at the analogue site around the crop stage of meiosis and anthesis closely matches those characteristics of the future climate scenario at the same growth stage. This is not only determined by air temperature but also relative humidity, radiation load, and water availability, since these factors also influence the expression of plant temperature.

activity.title: Development of abiotic (heat and combined drought and heat stress) and biotic screening sites in partnership with NARS to evaluate the resilience of key maize germplasm to future climates
activity.description: Climate predictions for EA and IGP show temperatures are likely to increase however very little research has been conducted in maize for tolerance to heat stress and combined heat and drought stress. There is currently limited phenotyping capacity for both heat stresss and combined heat and drought stress in EA and IGP. Repeatable screening protocols for drought stress can be achieved by screening in the dry season however screening for heat and combined heat and drought stress is much harder to manage resulting in loss of trials if a suitable stress level was not reached and large genotype x year variability. The establishment of a FATE facility will allow carefully controlled stress to be applied at the field level. Climate change is also likely to change the prevelance, diversity and responsiveness of maize pests and diseases, thus further work is required on screening for biotic stress.

activity.description: Fruit growers implement farm management practices that can either increase or substantially reduce carbon footprints. This activity is focused on developing a baseline of these practices among passionfruit, naranjil and guava growers in several locations around Colombia. A primary focus is on practices conducive to pest and disease control, and the rationale for depending either solely on chemical control or on integrated pest management systems.

activity.title: On farm evaluation of bean elite lines to correlate physiological traits with farmer traits (Kenya, Malawi)
activity.description: Farmers have their own way of observing their crops on a daily basis, and under varying climates from season to season. They also recognize plant traits that are conducive to better crop productivity. Scientists on the other hand define traits in their language. A comparison of farmer and scientist perspectives will permit validating scientist criteria, and receiving feedback from farmers on the value of those traits over time and in multiple environments.

activity.title: Quantify impact of climate change on maize and bean system in Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador.
activity.description: Central America is highly vulnerable to extreme events and unfavorable future climate conditions. A climate disaster often leads to crop failure and harms farmersâ€™ resilience and food security. Farmers have already experienced unforeseen climate variability in the past and need to cope with uncertainties every day to sustain agricultural production. Climate change means they will have to face additional long-term shifts of climate patterns as shown by global climate predictions. The project â€œTortillas on the Roasterâ€ seeks to predict site-specific changes in maize-bean production systems in order to inform and enable vulnerable farmers to act and respond to ongoing climate change through specific adaptation measures and increased capacity.

activity.title: Develop supply chain adaptation frame work, that outlines ways for supply chain to adapt jointly.
activity.description: Global climate change (GCC) presents serious challenges to agricultural systems as they strive to meet growing demand over the coming decades. Within these systems, food value chains are increasingly recognized as vital for development. Yet relatively little is known about the vulnerability of such chains to GCC, or their adaptability. This activity provides a framework to examine how food value chains adapt to the uncertain impacts posed by GCC. While intervention models mostly deal with measures for producers, we hypothesize that adaptation strategies must include the entire chain to achieve the scale needed to tackle GCC. We propose that comprehensive situation assessment is necessary to examine both behavior and assets â€“ two key attributes for adaptive capacities. Our framework examines three sets of attributes: 1) The general setup and nature of the supply chain, 2) rural livelihoodsâ€™ and food supply systemsâ€™ vulnerability to GCC, including downscaled crop suitability modeling to assess precise impacts of global climate change and 3) the behavior of people and entities involved in value creation and the institutions mediating them. The framework provides decision-makers with a scale-, crop- and site-independent road map to design and evaluate adaptation strategies to changing climate conditions. We test the framework on three case studies with differing supply chain characteristics and geographical contexts.

activity.title: Identifying crop wild relatives (CWR) collecting gaps for 80 genepools for climate change adaptation pre-breeding
activity.description: Crop Wild Relatives (CWR) are widely recognized as sources of genetic variability. Thanks to their close relatedness with cultivated species (CWR include crop ancestors) and the ecological niches they are adapted to, there is an increasingly growing interest in using CWR for adapting crops to the environmental conditions that climate change is expected to impose. Despite their importance and potential usefulness, CWR lack adequate representation in germplasm banks (e.g. Less than 5% of germplasm accessions of Cicer, Cajanus, Oryza and Phaseoluscorrespond to wild material). Gap analysis techniques enable us to identify which species need further collection and where in the world they are found.

activity.title: Multi-site evaluation of Brachiaria grasses (germplasm accessions and hybrids) and tropical forage legumes (species and germplasm accessions) for drought and waterlogging to respond to increased vulnerability due to climate change
activity.description: Tropical forage grasses and legumes grow over a wide range of environmental conditions. As of yet their response to climate change has not been well defined. Optimization of forage systems for future use with respect to yield and nutritional quality can therefore not be performed without new experimental evidence. Seasonal drought and waterlogging are dominant features of tropical agroecosystems, and both quantity and quality of forage production can be markedly affected by these stressors. Tropical grasses and legumes show considerable genotypic differences in drought resistance and forage quality. Multi-site evaluation of brachiaria grasses and legumes with farmer participation contributes to identification of climate-adapted forage options for integration into crop-livestock systems.

activity.title: Comparative adaptation differences between tepary bean and common bean characterized
activity.description: Tepary bean (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) is a desert species of the tertiary gene in relation to the common bean. Tepary has traits that make it particularly well adapted to extreme climates of heat and drought that are expected under climate change. It could serve either as a source of traits for the improvement of common bean, or as a useful species in itself. In either case, the acceptability of such as ideotype (small seeded with poor market potential; limited biomass; etc) should be tested with farmers before launching into a broader effort to utilize tepary.

Farmer exposure to risk and uncertainty is often aggravated by lack of information about weather, inputs, farm management practices or market prices, and this lack of information has an adverse impact on crop production and income. Some of these risks, for example the risk of a bad monsoon, affect agriculture as a whole, while other risks vary from region to region, and the severity of their impact depends on an individual farmer knowledge and coping ability. The evidence suggests that a farmer who receives quality, up-to-date information, and who has the ability to use that information, is able to lessen the effect of these risks.

For example, IWIS â€“which is coordinated by CIMMYT in collaboration with several hundred NARS scientists- has a data base encompassing information on the responses of thousands of modern wheat cultivars to a range of environments (including those that experienced temperature stress) and can be mined to identify cultivars adapted to different heat profiles. Information from crop and climate modeling exercises can permit more focused deployment of that germplasm to specific target regions, facilitated by socio-economic information to help with prioritization of the most vulnerable communities. Once identified, the target regions can be analyzed for apparent yield gaps that can be closed with better crop management as well as a range of alternative cropping systems that could ameliorate some of the negative impacts of climate change. This project aims to make a cost benefit analysis of these adaptive technologies, resulting in communicable outputs that can be used by a wide range of decision makers & farmer service providers (seed producers, NGOs, extension). In terms of prioritization, resource-poor farmers, particularly vulnerable groups and women, in at least 6 countries will be targeted. Towards the end of the project, stress adapted cultivars will be disseminated as nurseries and training in crop management practices and/or alternative cropping systems for target regions will be delivered to decision makers and farmer service providers in NARES and other relevant groups in the delivery chain.

The former tends to be better adapted to warmer climates and the second to temperate climates of the mid-to-high altitudes of the Andes and East Africa. With this effort we will refine the predictions of future adaptation by repeating the EcoCrop analysis with sites specific to each gene pool.

activity.description: Parasitic weeds, an important group of weeds in rice in sub-Saharan Africa, are progressively spreading due to their invasive nature and adaptive abilities. This is particularly worrisome considering projected demographic and climate changes. The most important parasitic weeds in rice are Striga hermonthica, S. asiatica and Rhamphicarpa fistulosa. We aim to prepare rice farmers in threatened areas against likely increasing infestations with these weeds by investigating vulnerable locations, effects of climate anomalies on parasitic-weed survival, reproduction and virulence, direct and indirect economic impacts, and sustainable management strategies for resource-poor farmers. Stakeholder interviews, field observations and measurements, yield-loss assessments and farmer-participatory experiments in hotspots (Benin, CÃ´te dâ€™Ivoire, Madagascar and Tanzania) combined with controlled climate chamber experiments and different modelling approaches will enable us to do meaningful predictions on future invasions and agronomic and economic impacts, and develop feasible management and policy strategies for prevention and containment to support stakeholder decision-making.

activity.title: Evaluating rice responses to pathogen strains under various climatic conditions
activity.description: To enhance Africaâ€™s rice production and reduce reliance on imports, rice yields per hectare need to be raised significantly, despite climate change. Major determinants of the current low yield levels per hectare per hectare (average of about 1 t ha-1 in upland ecologies, 1.5 to 2 t ha-1 in rainfed lowland ecologies and 3.0 to 4.0 t ha-1 in the irrigated ecologies) are biotic stresses, in particular two major rice diseases: blast and bacterial leaf blight, whose effect on rice growth and yield is very much affected by weather conditions, in particular temperature, air humidity and soil moisture status. The use of resistant varieties is the most economical and effective way of controlling these rice diseases in resource-poor farmersâ€™ fields. Unfortunately, because of the highly variable nature of the pathogens, it is difficult to manage blast disease through the use of resistant cultivars because of the breakdown of resistance. WARDA and partners are conducted research to analyze the structure of the pathogen populations in order to ensure safe deployment of resistant varieties. A focus on East Africa is very much needed, because information on rice diseases in that region is very scarce. The expression of plant resistance to blast and bacterial leaf blight is known to depend on climate. In many plant â€“ pathogen systems, climatic conditions impact both on the occurrence and gravity of diseases attributable to micro-organisms such as fungi, bacteria, viruses and insects and on plant response to diseases. The impact of climate change on blast and bacterial blight diseases of rice has not been documented. According to the International Panel on Climate Change, East Africa and especially the Great Lakes Region are among the more vulnerable regions in Africa to climate change. The trend is towards increasing temperatures and declining rainfall, all factors that may intensify disease occurrence and severity. Disease occurrence may deter farmers from investing in intensification measures because of risks related to yield losses or even total crop failure. The development of rice varieties that resist these diseases under current and future climates is, therefore, of great importance. This will require the evaluation of current pathogen population structures and the likely impact of climate change on the evolution of host-pathogen relationships. With such knowledge it will be possible to mitigate the impact of climate change on rice disease resistance in East Africa and enhance and protect the livelihoods of smallholder rice farmers.

activity.title: Identify promising incentives, institutions and market-based mechanisms and policies for adoption of conservation agriculture by smallholder farmers in EA
activity.description: The economies of most countries in Africa are heavily depend on the agriculture sector. The performance of this sector , however, is constrained by several biophysical and socioeconomic factors. Soil fertility depletion is considered a major biophysical factor limiting per capita food production for most smallholder farmers in the region. When no external inputs are used, plots require long fallow periods to replenish nutrients taken up by crops and washed away by erosion. However, as the population increases and the availability of new land to exploit decreases, allowing plots to lie fallow has become more and more difficult, and continuous cropping has become commonplace in Africa. This has resulted in a vicious cycle of poor agricultural productivity, low investment capacity, continued soil degradation, and further pressure on available lands to generate necessary food supplies. Greater adoption and diffusion of conservation agriculture practices (CAPs) offers a means of addressing some of these problems. The potential benefits of CAPs lie not only in conserving but also in potentially enhancing the natural resource base without sacrificing yield levels. Despite their benefits and a number of national and international initiatives to encourage farmers to invest in them, the adoption rate of CAPs is still low in rural areas of developing countries. In order to address this, a greater understanding is required of the farmers' incentives, institutions, market-based mechanisms and policies that influence the adoption of conservation agriculture by smallholder farmers in EA.

activity.title: Contribution to framework and databases allowing for integrated decision making with respect to adaptation, mitigation and policy interventions
activity.description: Ensuring global food security in the face of climate change. The global community must find a way to provide food and water security for a population expected to reach 9 billion by 2050. Global carrying capacity for food production and our ability to protect carbon-rich and bio-diverse natural ecosystems from conversion to cropland ultimately depend on achieving maximum possible yields on every hectare of currently used arable land. Yet for most major crop producing regions of the world, including data-rich regions such as the U.S. Corn Belt and The Netherlands, there are no reliable data on yield potential (Yp). Water resources to support rainfed and irrigated agriculture also are under pressure, making the efficiency with which water is converted to food, water productivity (WP), another critical benchmark. The target is to find the exploitable yield gap (Yg)â€”the difference between current average farm yields and Yp. Accurate estimates of Yp, Yg, and WP, and their year-to-year variability, are critical to increase yields and make the best use of land and water resources. Unfortunately, previous efforts to estimate Yp lack agronomic relevance. The Global Yield Gap and Water Productivity Atlas (hereafter called the Atlas) will provide a web-based platform for estimating Yp, Yg, and WP that is transparent, accessible, reproducible, geospatially explicit, agronomically robust and applied in a consistent manner throughout the world. The Atlas will enable farmers, governments, policy makers, foundations, the private sector, and others to: (i) identify regions with the greatest potential to increase food supply and water use efficiency; (ii) provide input to economic global models (either computable general equilibrium models or partial equilibrium or agricultural sector models) that assess food security and land use; (iii) prioritize research investments, and (iv) evaluate the impact of climate change and other issues that deal with water, food, and weather. The Atlas is an international project that requires on-the-ground efforts because it is based on local data from each of the world's major crop production regions on soil and long-term weather, planting and harvest dates of major crops in existing cropping systems. A standard protocol for assessing Yp, Yg, and WP will be developed by leading scientists around the globe and it will be based on a strong agronomic foundation. This protocol will be applied in a bottom-up process that uses local experts and networks to provide knowledge about crop management and productivity and existing soil and climate databases. These data will be used with the most appropriate crop simulation models and a geographic information system (GIS) to produce detailed maps with associated databases displayed and accessible through an interactive web-based platform suitable for expert and non-expert users. To the extent that IP restrictions allow, all data and models used in the Atlas will be made publicly available.

activity.description: CCAFS is trying to systematize and make available the information generated in the Centers through AgTrials and to use this data to generate information for the technology produced by the Centers and Partners to help farmers adapt to progressive climate change. Unfortunately, most breeding trials do not record growth and development traits in the rigorous manner required by modelers to estimate the parameters to model the expected behavior of a crop under different climatic and management conditions. All the breeding trials record biomass at harvest and visual indicators that allow scientists to make germplasm selections and recommendations for different conditions. We expect to develop tools based on numerical and artificial intelligence algorithms with minimum data input: location, planting and harvesting dates, harvested product and some qualitative aspects. activity.title: Developing methods to jointly model geo-spatial climate covariates such as topography, soil fertility and pests
activity.description: Efficient site-specific agricultural management requires a thorough quantitative knowledge of (i) spatial and temporal variability of crop yield within an agricultural field or a region and ii) factors and interactions influencing crop yields. The main factors influencing crop yields are field topography and soil properties, including soil fertility and moisture. Complexity of crop yield variability often could not be fully characterized by traditional statistical approaches. A multifractal analysis can provide detailed additional information about data spatial variability and has been utilized for analysis of various spatially distributed natural phenomena. An extension of multifractal theory for analyzing more than one variable called joint multifractal theory was developed in the physical theory. Joint multifractal theory can be used for conducting simultaneous analyses of several multifractal measures existing on the geometric support and for studying relationships between the measures. As the topography controls soil water distribution in semiarid environments where water is the major growth-limiting factor, in this study topographic attributes that best represent the spatial variability and scaling properties of crop yield will be identified and used to improve the capacity to model yield across scales under different climates. This approach aims at reducing the uncertainty of forecasted yields under climate change scenarios thus improving the reliability of CCAFS outputs needed for decision making. We will start by showing the importance of spatial variability in assessing productivity. The second step is to test the suitability of the proposed approach to improve geospatial yield forecasting when topography and soil-water processes are incorporated in the model; and third, we will attempt introducing the pest component in the model aiming at improving CCAFS capability of jointly modeling most important processes limiting productivity under climate change conditions.

activity.title: Develop a climate downscaling methodology based on wavelets, multifractals and neural networks
activity.description: Crop-simulation models provide an important tool for assessing the potential implications of seasonal forecasts on agriculture. However, the coarse spatial resolution of global and regional circulation models used in seasonal predictions makes it generally necessary to downscale these predictions to scales suitable for driving crop models. Precipitation and temperature downscaling improve the coarse resolution and poor local representation of global climate models and help end users to assess the likely hydrological impacts of climate change and should also enhance modelersâ€™ ability to generate more realistic climatic-change scenarios. In the case of rainfall, end users demand reliable representations of precipitation intensities and temporal and spatial variability, as well as, physical consistency, independent of region and season. In this sense, remaining gaps are uncertainties arising from sparse data; representation of extreme summer precipitation, sub daily precipitation, and full precipitation fields on fine scales; capturing changes in small-scale processes and their feedback on large scales; and errors inherited from the driving global climate model and its propagation towards regional models. Unfortunately, conventional downscaling methods do not seem to account for the spatial variations across scales. The non-linear approaches used in this activity are anchored in statistical physics and are hypothesized to better account for physical and orographic processes influencing spatial climatic variability. We thus expect to deliver products more in line with the demands of the end-users and complementary to other CCAFS downscaling efforts. In close collaboration with Climatic research groups, downscaling products will be used as input to crop models to ascertain the performance of downscaling protocols comparing different climate input and contrasting modeling results with historical yield data and expert knowledge. Models will also be used to assess how global warming will affect the ability to grow food, at different spatial and temporal scales.

activity.description:
Climate information, including historical and real-time, plays an important role in planning and management of agricultural operations. When properly integrated with the decision making process, climate information has the potential to moderate the risk and vulnerability of agricultural systems to variable climatic conditions especially in semi-arid tropics where productivity and profitability of agriculture is directly influenced by within and between the season variability in rainfall. The need for such integration is more important now than ever due to the growing concern about the climate change and its impacts on agriculture.
Historically, meteorological organizations have collected and are maintaining huge databases of climatic information. But, very little effort has gone to turn this data into useful products that can be used by research and developmental programs. To a large extent this is constrained by complex nature of the agricultural systems and lack of appropriate tools to properly quantify the relationships between climate and agricultural production. Recent advances in our understanding of the agricultural systems coupled with those in the computing technology resulted in the development of a number of tools and methods that are extremely useful in conducting a detailed analysis on the soil-plant-climate systems. Unfortunately, use of these tools in most developing countries is limited by non-availability of required skills. This activity is aimed at enhancing the skills of researchers and extension agents in using the tools to better understand the variability and trends in climate, understanding the risks associated with the uncertainty in seasonal rainfall and develop appropriate management options that reduce risk and assist in capitalizing the opportunities. Climate information includes seasonal climate forecasts.

Rice production in delta regions such as the Mekong in Vietnam and the Ganges-Brahmaputra in Bangladesh is of outmost importance at regional, national and trans-national scale. Due to the direct impacts of sea level rise, delta regions are among the most vulnerable environments to climate change. Recent development in rice breeding and crop management offer distinct prospects to cope with of sea rise and other climate change impacts. Improved resiliencies to flooding and salinity have been among the key traits integrated into new rice varieties. Improved heat resilience is the focus of newly launched breeding program at IRRI, so that that targeted dissemination in heat-prone environments may in future avert projected yield losses. Water-saving techniques have been developed to reduce irrigation requirement, but these approaches also offer innate opportunities for coping with drought while maintaining high yield potentials. Previously, farmers have often been reluctant to adopt changes in farming practice, e.g. modified irrigation patterns, as these options have been perceived to carry detrimental effects or certain risks to yield performance. Moreover, the project will develop guidelines for Measurement, Reporting and Verification (MRV) as well as innovative approaches for recording emissions in situ. These guidelines and techniques will integrate necessary information for reliable quantification of emission savings that can be used by future mitigation projects. In addition to water saving, changes in crop residue management offer the greatest mitigation potential in rice production. Rice straw is often burned in Asia entailing considerable GHG emissions. In order to maintain food security, economic and social benefits of agriculture and natural resources in the face of known climate variability and anticipated climate change, researchers would work to develop and implement basin-wide climate change adaptation strategies that will enhance the resilience of communities. They would work to strengthen local and district institutions to better manage natural resources and build resilience to climate change. They would facilitate and help build cross-basin and cross-sectoral natural resources management and planning policy for climate change throughout the basin. Researchers would also work to improve household and enterprise capacity to adapt, and finally, they would work to mitigate the effects of climate change through improved forest management and governance. The Malawi Government recently approved the National Adaptation Programme of Action for climate change. The efforts of the WorldFish Center and partners would be complimentary to the efforts of the national government. Partners would include Leadership for Environment and Development (LEAD), the Forestry Research Institute of Malawi and the National Herbarium and Botanical Gardens of Malawi.

activity.description:
Index insurance is an innovative financial product that helps rural households manage large covariate shocks to agricultural income. Current research is increasingly showing that an effective risk management strategy in the face of climate change will require a combination of indexed insurance, savings and credit and that the correct combination of these three financial products will likely depend on the nature of climatic shocks and rural financial markets
If rural communities have access to such risk management tools they can increase the degree to which they are able to withstand climate risks. This in turn is likely to increase their investments in technologies in which the return is dependent on the climate. The ultimate effect of insurance on the resilience of rural households is thus an empirical question that is likely to vary depending on the situation being considered.

activity.title: Study on the economic viability of climate change mitigation through the use biochar
activity.description:
Work completed by IFPRI and collaborators in Ghana, indicates that while the potential for carbon sequestration through carbon accumulation in agricultural soils is a substantial reality, its quantification presents considerable challenges. In order to compute the amount of carbon sequestered, one has to create a baseline of soil carbon for a period of 15 â€“ 20 years and this requires predicting farmersâ€™ agricultural decisions for the same period. Soil organic carbon content is highly dependent on crop choices, input usage, and on agronomic practices implemented, and it is particularly difficult to predict smallholder farmersâ€™ choices for long periods of time. In fact, poor farmers have a very short planning horizon and decisions about input usage and agronomic practices are dependent on market vagaries, family size, and other hard-to-predict factors. There is, though, one practice in the area of study that is recurrent, widespread, and very predictable: slash and burn. This practice is used to clear a plot of land after a few years of fallow. Slash and burn saves labor, kills pests, and returns a small amount of minerals to the soil. However, the transformation of woody fallow growth into biochar, which directly avoids CO2 emissions and could be used as a soil amendment, could be a viable alternative to current practices.
Biochar is charcoal produced from biomass using an anaerobic process called pyrolysis and its chemical characteristics make it particularly valuable. The form of carbon present in biochar is thought to be stable in the soil for hundreds of years. Furthermore, biochar can increase soil water- and nutrient-holding capacity with direct positive effects on yields, particularly in nutrient-deficient soils. The stability of the biochar carbon, the immediate reduction of CO2 emissions, and the positive effects on yields, substantially reduce problems related to permanence and MRV that limit the viability of other climate change mitigation methods in agriculture.

Beneficial microorganisms can play a substantial role in enhancing yield production in cowpea (Ngakou et al., 2007). In particular, mycorrhiza and endophytic fungi can interact in eliciting defense reactions in response to attack by insect pests, and this model is being tested on cowpea pests such as the cowpea pod borer Maruca vitrata (Lepidoptera, Crambidae). On-going experiments have showed up to 62% larval mortality when pod borer larvae are fed with cowpea plant parts (leaves, flowers and pods), whose seeds have been inoculated with endophytic strains of the entomopathogenic fungus Beauveria bassiana in pot experiments. We are currently co-inoculating cowpea seeds with mycorrhizal fungi, and preliminary observations indicate possible synergies between the two beneficial organisms. In view of the increased periods of erratic rainfall which either leads to drought or floods (or even a combination of them during the same cropping season), it becomes important to test these interaction in a range of gradients of water supply. The influence of these different degrees of water supply (and their changes over time) will be simulated both in rain-out shelters, and also in the open field by sequential plantings from the wet into the dry season (using irrigation facilities if needed).

Accurate soil data that represent local soil conditions are important for the simulation of the soil water and nitrogen balances, especially for rainfed conditions where water is limiting. Soil data can be extremely variable across space, and scaling up from point-based simulations to grid-based simulation provides considerable challenges related to input data. There is now a WISE Version 3.1 database, and converting this into model format would allow many more additional soil profiles to be utilized, that may be more representative of the local conditions.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Global Mapping of Intensive Livestock Production Systems
activity.description: Population growth, urbanisation and changes in dietary preferences associated mostly with increasing wealth are driving massive increases in demand for livestock products. The implications of this rapid growth in demand and supply of animal source foods are manifold. Whilst presenting opportunities for many involved in the livestock sector, it also poses significant challenges in terms of threatening poor peoplesâ€™ livelihoods; introducing animal and public health risks; reducing the diversity of animal genetic resources; and imposing a strain on the environment. It is thus important to understand the driving forces behind the intensification and concentration of livestock production in order to determine where intensification is occurring now and to predict where it is likely to occur in the future. Such information can be used to guide research, development and policies that assist people in adapting to these changing circumstances and that help to mitigate the negative effects that may arise through such changing patterns of production.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

partner.name: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

activity.title: Refinement of global cropland extent data layers
activity.description: Reliable global data sets of cropland extent would seem to be a key resource for many different purposes. For example, the future agricultural potential of tropical areas will play a critical role in meeting the challenge of future food security. While crop yield can be estimated with some reliability using a limited sample of ground observations, reliable crop acreages and their spatial distribution are rarely available. Different remote sensing products are available, but comparison work (see, for example, Fritz et al. (2010), â€œComparison of global and regional land cover maps with statistical information for the agricultural domain in Africaâ€, International Journal of Remote Sensing 31 (9), 2237-2256), indicates that some products do better in some places and some in others. The work here seeks to produce a hybrid product that combines the best of the available information.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

partner.name: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis

activity.title: Developing generic tools for characterizing agricultural systems for climate and global change studies (Impact Lite)
activity.description: The objective of the work is to implement a household-level survey using the IMPACT lite tool to characterize livelihood activities in the CCAFS sites for climate change studies. This will involve the following: 1) testing of the tool at each of the CCAFS sentinel sites; 2) identification of survey teams and coordinators across regions; 3) contracting survey agents; 4) training of the teams to carry out the curvey work; 5) support of the teams to deliver clean datasets; 6) compilation of the global database.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Impact model wiki design, development and testing (AgriMod.org)
activity.description: The aim is to develop a web resource that will serve as a central hub for information on agricultural modelling activities (primarily encompassing biophysical models of agricultural processes). It will streamline the process of accessing resources and sources of information and data for modelling and research purposes. The aim is to create a site that will facilitate greater levels of co-operation between modelling groups, data providers, funding organisations and stakeholder beneficiaries, in order to increase modelling research capacity to support food security and climate change initiatives. The purpose of the web site will be to serve the global research community by providing a resource, information and discussion centre that facilitates more and better quality research by the agricultural modelling and wider environmental and socio-economic research communities. It will also serve as a centre for contact between the scientific research community and policy development stakeholders at regional, national and international levels. The rationale for developing this web resource is the recognition of the need to facilitate greater up-take of modelling activities, particularly in developing countries, to support national capabilities to research food security and climate change impacts, mitigation and adaptation. There is further need to streamline the process by which new model activities are developed, and by which existing initiatives can be improved, to better support actions on improving food security and tackling climate change.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Livestock production model intercomparison and improvement
activity.description: CCAFS is collaborating with AgMIP, the Agricultural Model Improvement and Intercomparison Project, and one area in which CCAFS is seeking to provide support is in ruminant livestock models. CCAFS has commissioned a consultant to lead a comparison of existing livestock models.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Data management strategy, support tools, and creating and maintaining data portals
activity.description: Theme 4.2 is collaborating with the consortium office and CIMMYT to create a CCAFS-wide data management strategy. This will involve the creation of support tools and data portals to house the data collected by CCAFS baseline studies and other research initiatives of the program.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

partner.name: International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center
Statistical Services Centre, University of Reading

activity.title: CCAFS Near-Term Climate Project
activity.description: Climate information is used in agriculture and food security on a range of timescales, from days (weather), months (seasonal outlooks) to decades (climate change scenarios) (Hellmuth et al. 2011). Providing information on climate between seasonal and decadal timescales has proved difficult, falling into the period where traditional forecast skill dies away and the climate change signal is difficult to detect against natural variability. Yet much policy, planning and investment decision-making falls into this time horizon (Stafford-Smith et al. 2011). Both the seasonal forecasting community and the climate change scenario community have developed techniques and methods for provision and communication of climate infomation, as well as the use of climate information in impacts assessment, planning, risk mitigation, adaptation, etc. Decision-making on 1-10 year timescales may require a hybrid approach that draws on btoh traditions. Yet there has been little research on the climate information needs on these timescales, on methods that can provide the required information, or on how to use what will necessarily be uncertain information in planning and decision making.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: G-Range (global rangeland model) development and testing
activity.description: Temperate and tropical rangelands occur throughout the world and support the livelihoods of millions of livestock-owning households. Global change, such as climate change associated with a build-up of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gasses, is anticipated to alter the services that rangelands provide. One means of increasing the likelihood that households, enterprises, and land managers will be able to adapt to future changes is if future conditions can be anticipated. A method of anticipating future conditions is through using simulations, where inputs into the simulations are modified as predicted in change scenarios. A means of simulating future changes in rangelands across the globe is sought. While numerous grassland and rangeland simulation models have been developed, none is amenable to use directly in global simulations. The work here seeks to develop a process-based simulation model that is spatially explicit and of moderate complexity. The model will allow global analyses of native rangelands and the changes they may undergo.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Demonstrating a generic framework and tools for modeling resilience of farm households to climate related risk
activity.description: The ability to model the impact of climate-related risk on rural households, and to evaluate the impacts of risk management interventions ex-ante, is a priority need within CCAFS Theme 2, "Adaptation through Managing Climate Risk." However, a simple static approach to risk analysis is not adequate to account for the effects of antecedent conditions, or the time structure of climate and other stochastic drivers, on the risk that a rural household encounters; or the cumulative impact of risk on a household's ability to meet its livelihood goals. This activity aims to develop a resilience framework and household modeling tools that will provide an advantage over simple, static approaches to risk analysis.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Vulnerability assessments at sub-national level for selected countries in at least 2 CCAFS regions
activity.description: As a continuation of the earlier vulnerability mapping work, the researchers will, in one or more CCAFS target regions, examine the impact of different climate change thresholds that are specific to particular contexts and food systems, using different coping capacity indicators at household and regional levels. The researchers will also investigate the consequences of climate change for the less well-studied components of food security: access to food, utilization of food and stability of food security year round. The review will also consider the potential GHG emission impacts from issues such as ensuring fair and equitable distribution of food and implemting people's right to safe and nutritous food. The paper will review all available evidence on these issues with the aim of identifying knowledge gaps, and suggest how research could fill these over the next five years.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Quantification of regional scenarios using global integrated models
activity.description: The development and use of scenarios functions as a platform for the exchange and application of knowledge and experience between CCAFS researchers and policy makers, privator sectors, NGOs and other societal actors. Because scenarios allow for the capturing of uncertainties and systems complexity in a coherent and plausible yet surprising and challenging fashion, scenarios are also a tool for generating shared engagement. The next step in the scenarios process is to explore the implications of these qualitative scenarios through quantigication using GEC and economic models that focus on food security assessment. The quantification of the scenarios will increase their credibility and plausibility and their usefulness as contexts for the testing of policies and strategies. Initially, the scenarios quantification will be done through the close collaboration of two modeling teams--a team working with the IMPACT model developed at IFPRI and a team working with the GLOBIOM model developed at IIASA.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

partner.name: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis

activity.title: Review of climate change communications and social learning in climate change
activity.description: Phase 1: While a large body of literature is concerned with climate change communications and social learning in the developed world, less is available or applicable to the developing world. The differences between climate change communications approaches and social learning approaches should be articulated. Various approaches and tools are being developed and applied by the development community and the aim is to review the existing approaches, tools and decision aids that are applicable in this context, as well as the major stakeholders involved in the CCAFS target regions. The abilities of different communication tools to bring out stakeholdersâ€™ engagement in the exchange of perspectives on CCAFS issues should be a central consideration. Phase 2: In late 2011, CCAFS â€˜Theme 4â€™ issued a call for proposals for people and organizations to help develop a CCAFS â€˜strategy on communication and social learningâ€™. IDS/IIED were selected for the review and contributed to the subsequent process of designing and facilitating a May 2012 workshop in Addis Ababa. Drawing on the IDS/IIED review of current climate change communications and social learning approaches, tools and decision aids, as well as the Addis Workshop, we want to identify the main strengths and weaknesses in targeting specific stakeholders, as well as the gaps that will inform a CCAFS strategy to engage in this area. We are interested in different kinds of communication approaches, tools and decision aids for different levels of stakeholders (such as farmers, community groups, local governments, etc.). IIED and IDS will collaborate on this project and work closely with CCAFS, ILRI-KMIS and the mechanisms of engagement that are being established.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Agricultural land cover data for Latin America and southeast Asia in 2005 (GEOSHARE)
activity.description: The Land Use and Global Environment research program within the department of Geography at McGill University is a leading developer of global data on agricultural land cover and use. Our previous global data for year 2000 (Monfreda et al., 2008; Ramankutty et al., 2008) have been used by in a variety of environmental and economic analysis (Betts et al., 2007; Gordon et al., 2005; Taheripour et al., 2010). McGill is a key node of the GEOSHARE project (http://www.geoshareproject.org/). As part of the pilot phase of GEOSHARE, McGill will develop agricultural land cover data for SubSaharan Africa and South Asia for the year 2005. Through this CCAFS contract, McGill will extend that work to Southeast Asia and Latin America, and to the rest of the world if time permits.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Sponsoring of participants for AgMIP workshop
activity.description: The Agricultural Model Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP) is a distributed climate-scenario simulation exercise for historical model intercomparison and future climate change conditions with participation of multiple crop and world agricultural trade modeling groups around the world. The goals of AgMIP are to improve substantially the characterization of risk of hunger and world food security due to climate change and to enhance adaptation capacity in both developing and developed countries. AgMIP is designed to provide an integrated, transdisciplinary framework to assess climate impacts on the agricultural sector and will build capacity for continuing agricultural assessment and management in developing countries under changing climate conditions. Given the congruence of its aims with those of CCAFS, ways are being explored to build synergies between the two efforts. The first step was to involve developing country partners in the AgMIP start-up meeting in late 2010. CCAFS has continued to sponsor participants from its target regions in subsequent AgMIP meetings. At the October 2012 meeting in Rome, CCAFS will sponsor 3-4 people from each of its regions.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Science meeting on systems analysis tools
activity.description: Several CRPs are centrally involved in studying complex agro-ecosystems in which there may be both synergies and trade-offs involved in attaining the development outcomes of increased household incomes, increased food security, and sustainable enhancements to ecological services. While the specific research questions and challenges may vary between CRPs and regions, the approaches and tools needed to study such complex systems are often similar. Understanding system dynamics, identifying tipping points, and understanding trade-offs across temporal and spatial scales and actors requires knowledge to be integrated across several domains, including the biophysical and the socio-economic. A workshop will be organised with some 15-20 scientists engaged in research in relevant CRPs. Several case studies will be developed prior to the workshop, to illustrate the challenges that need to be addressed. Participants will include a mix of CRPS scientists and a few external speakers that can bring novel and relevant system approaches from diverse backgrounds to the meeting.

activity.description: CCAFS is making extensive use of the DSSAT cropping system models and has recognized the need for research to expand the capabilities of DSSAT to include crops that are of high importance to that project (e.g., cassava, pigeopea, and yam) and to improve the quality of weather and soil inputs to the models for their use globally. The research activities will be carried out at the University of Florida and Washington State University with collaboration with other CCAFS scientists in CIAT, ILRI and elsewhere.

activity.description: The consultant will work with scientists from University of Florida, Washington State University, and CIAT to further develop and evaluate a cassava model, within the framework of the Cropping System computer Model (CSM) of DSSAT, for application to both policy and agronomic problems.

activity.title: Initiation of a case study at one CCAFS site on developing approaches to support smallholder decision making, to link with both the met service work and the household modelling work
activity.description: Farmers in Sub-Sahara Africa, operating in risky and unpredictable environments, have to make decisions with very limited information available to them. Research on farmersâ€™ perceptions of climate change and variability indicate that in many communities there are perceptions, particularly regarding amounts and timing of rainfall, that are i) not generally reflected in analysed climatic data and ii) contradictory. Consequently farmers may be making decisions and implementing both short term management practices and longer term strategies that are inappropriate. Analysed historical data (from daily records made over several decades) is increasingly being made available in several countries (through work undertaken by UoR with partner institutions). At the same time a range of participatory approaches (including participatory farm management methods [Dorward et al 2003]) exist that could be adapted and used to communicate with farmers about analysed climate information in ways that enable farmers to make more informed (and therefore improved) short and longer term livelihood, farm and crop decisions. Key to this is understanding what information farmers want and need, being able to provide it in ways that are easy to understand and at the same time enable facilitate meaningful consideration of implications. Forecasts (long, medium and short) can provide further information of value to planning and decision making. Attempts to introduce these to farmers have had mixed success. With the improved understanding from the above there is scope to add some of these to the information that farmers receive in a more integrated and useful way. Preliminary fieldwork in Zimbabwe (June/July 2012) confirmed the need for and potential of research on this topic. Smallholders, working with extension staff successfully used a range of approaches in the initial steps 1-4 (steps summarised later in this document). Work is required to test the full approach at a range of locations with different characteristics (climate, agriculture, socioeconomic), draw lessons and facilitate wider implementation and scaling up. Capacity building amongst service providers, particularly extension services and NGOs that work directly with smallholders forms a necessary and important part of the project.

leader.name: Assemble Data and Tools for Analysis and Planning

activity.title: Development of global agroforestry suitability maps in a changed climate
activity.description: South Asia has about half of the Worldâ€™s poor, and the poverty wide spread throughout the region. The region is characterized by low resource base, few income generating opportunities, a web of socio-political conflicts and low extent of education. These factors and inappropriate policies lead to food and income insecurity and make the community vulnerable to climate change effects. The region recognizes agroforestry as an important avenue for improving livelihoods, harnessing environmental services and buffering against climate change, and each country has estimated the potential area for agroforestry. For example, India estimated 28 m ha; 18 m ha in the rainfed and 10 m ha in irrigated lands. However, which agroforestry system would be suitable in which agro-climatic condition is not known, and this has limited the practice of agroforestry in most of them. Therefore, it requires the assessment of agroforestry trajectories, and development of appropriate methodologies to do so.

Maharana Pratap University of Agriculture and Technology

activity.title: Climate change impact projection and adaptation planning framework
activity.description: The quantitative basis for identifying climate change adaptation options for Sub-Saharan Africa is small. Reliable weather data for crop modeling and other applications is scarce and difficult to obtain, and even where it exists, it is not easily translated into agriculturally meaningful metrics. Quantitative climate change impact projections are prerequisites for any attempt to adapt to climate change in a scientifically credible way.

activity.title: Response of grassland growth to climate change on the Tibetan Plateau (TP)
activity.description: Vegetation growth, which was regulated by climate change to some extent, has an essential function in regulating carbon and energy exchange in terrestrial ecosystems. Considerable evidence shows that continuous warming occurred in the late 20th century and 2000 to 2009 has been the warmest years. Several studies have shown that the increase of vegetation growth during the 1980s -1990s may be stalled or even reversed in some region of Eurasia during last decade. Various reasons have been found, for instance drought, spring cooling etc. Previous studies demonstrated that spring phenology on Tibetan Plateau (TP) has advanced before mid-1990s and retreated afterwards, which primarily causes the shortening of the length of growing season. This will eventually lead to variation in vegetation growth. No detailed research has been done in terms of vegetation growth response to climate change under the context of complex climate change and shortened growing season on TP.

activity.title: Studies on management effects on GHG emissions, especially nitrous oxide, in Indonesia.
Multi-site agricultural trial evaluation database for climate change analysis
activity.description: The CCAFS multi-site agricultural trial initiative, started in 2010, builds on the wealth of technology evaluations available for modeling climate change adaptation by standardizing and consolidating data that will be used by the scientific community to build adaptation â€œroad maps.â€ The effort has now completed initial development of databases, file repositories, web interfaces, communication protocols and processes for further development of a powerful information resource for the agricultural research community. Project partnerships have been developed to motivate the growth and development of the information resource. Significant advances made with GCP, the Tropical Legumes project, UC-Riverside, Monsanto, AgMips and the CGIAR centers. Efforts at fund raising have been mixed, with good leveraging of co-finance (GCP, Tropical Legumes, etc), but lacking a major grant for future sustainability. Efforts in the next phase of the trials project should focus on technical and process improvements, securing project sustainability, improving partnerships and increasing the number of trials held in the database. In 2012 the Agtrials project should become consolidated and mature leaving a system that is fully ready to be utilized by the international crop improvement community.

activity.title: Development of a method to study farmer's social, cultural and gender specific barriers for enabling behavioral change and improve adaptive capacity, based on farmers exchanges between climatic analogues locations (Farms of the Future Africa)
activity.description: The 'Farms of the Future' project will use the CCAFS climate analogue tool to connect farmers to their possible climate futures via farm visits. Through this novel anthropological approach of farmer-to-farmer exchanges between spatial analogues, CCAFS aims to establish a sound methodology allowing identification of social, cultural and gender specific barriers for enabling behavioral change, therefore, an increased adaptive capacity. The project will particularly improve understanding of social and cultural perceptions of future climates, local practices and available tools for enabling change, as well as cultural, economic, or institutional obstacles to such adaptive change (e.g., no existing market for cultivation of an otherwise promising substitution crop). The adopted approach will allow the participatory diagnosis of capacities and needs, thus aiding in the design of community-appropriate adaptation strategies. Once refined, the methodology will be global enough to be applicable anywhere. It will provide policy makers with key socio-cultural information to tailor local adaptation strategies and habilitate scientists to validate computational models with analogue proxies and to ground mathematical projections with qualitative, real world assessments. Furthermore, it will help refine the analogue tool itself to include non-biophysical variables.

activity.description: The purpose of this agreement is to establish a 3 year strategic research endeavor of University of Florida, to jointly develop and undertake with CIAT and CCAFS, a set of activities aiming to strengthen capacity in gender analysis and research at our respective institutions.

activity.description: Scientific evidence gathered in the last couple of decades suggests that climate conditions are changing rapidly and that this trend will likely continue and even accelerate. These anticipated changes in climate baseline, variability and extremes will have far-reaching consequences on agricultural production, posing additional challenges to meeting food security for a growing world population. As climate â€œmigratesâ€ between regions, it will disproportionally affect resource-poor and marginalized farmers who have lower adaptive capacities but may depend entirely on agriculture for their livelihoods. Therefore, male and female farmers alike need to enhance their adaptive capacities. Achieving adapted farming systems for changing climate conditions in space and time will require the development of new technologies and testing across a range of pilot sites, as well as modeling activities to outâ€scale the potential of individual adaptation options across a wideâ€range of geographies. The CCAFS â€œFarms of the Futureâ€ project will use the climate analogue tool to connect farmers to their possible climate futures via farm visits. This project will address the following working hypothesis: by identifying and connecting analogue sites, research can: 1) enable farmers to better envision how their site-specific agricultural future might look, and 2) permit targeted on-the-ground testing of cropping systemsâ€™/technologiesâ€™ climate resilience. In sum, we are hoping to learn the potential of the climate analogues tool/methodology to improve farmersâ€™ adaptive capacities and preparedness for eventual transformational adaptation.

activity.title: Consolidating seasonal forecast communication workshop and evaluation in Kaffrine, Senegal
activity.description: CCAFS is establishing a network of participatory pilot demonstrations that will engage rural communities and other local stakeholders at benchmark locations to identify, develop and evaluate suites of promising risk management interventions. The provision and use of seasonal climate forecasts has been identified as a promising climate risk management intervention. This project aims to consolidate the longer-term partnership in Kaffrine by testing the design and communication of downscaled, probabilistic seasonal forecasts; and evaluating their impact on farmersâ€™ management and livelihood outcomes.

activity.description: Seasonal-to-interannual variability of the climate system has major impacts on the populations of West Africa, one of the worldâ€™s lowest-income regions. Climate information at the local level is critical in helping small-scale farmers improve agricultural management decisions. In most rural areas, local farmers and other stakeholders have limited access to and use of seasonal climate forecasts. There is therefore a need to strengthen and capacitate local farmers and other end-users to use seasonal forecast information to improve agricultural management decision processes at local level.

The project will assess levels of diversity of different major crops in benchmark sites in East Africa, assess the current vulnerability of varieties and varietal portfolios, and identify varietal diversification needs and opportunities. Based on this information, varietal diversification strategies will be designed and tested in the field, introducing existing landrace and improved materials to farmers. Applying the approach in the CCAFS benchmark sites would make it possible to compare the impact determine which advantages and disadvantages it has relative to alternative technologies and interventions.

activity.description: Climate variability and climate change are and are likely to have major impacts on food security, especially in rainfed, dryland areas. activity.title: Participatory Evaluation and Promotion of integrated sorghum - legume technologies for improved food security and income in Wote district of Eastern Kenya
activity.description: Increasingly-recognized environmental threats such as climate change, land degradation and biodiversity loss have added new dimensions to the on-going challenges such as drought, increasing population pressure, and rising costs of food and inputs in the dry tropics. Most of the inhabitants of the dryland areas struggle to wrest a meagre living from agriculture and tragically, they are missing out on large potential productivity gains that are biologically possible given the soils, crops and climates of these areas, as proven by decades of research across a wide range of dryland locations (World Bank, 2008). Sorghum (Sorghum bicolor L.) as a C4, hot-season cereal crop, is adapted to a wide range of environmental and soil fertility conditions and has been termed it as one of the â€œClimate Change Ready Cropsâ€ (ASARECA, 2010). Small scale farmers often intercrop sorghum with legumes such as cowpea, greengram, and lablab bean to provide the protein that supplement the carbohydrates and starch from sorghum. This project will bring to the mainstream, the sorghum system and some legume crops with inherent resilience to drought and hence enhance the food basket for households in the dry areas. The goal is to improve the livelihoods of the poor rural smallholder farming households in arid and semi-arid areas of Eastern Kenya. The main objective of the project is to support the evaluation, dissemination and uptake of new sorghum and legume technologies and also explore opportunities to create farmer market linkages. The project will focus on Wote district - one of the CCAFS sites in Eastern Kenya. The project will be implemented in collaboration with KARI Katumani. and the extension staff in 5 selected villages in Wote district.

activity.title: Increasing Women's Resilience to Confront Climate Change
activity.description: There is some evidence to suggest that unequal access to and control over assets make women particularly vulnerable to the negative impacts of climate change both in terms of their sensitivity to climate shocks and their adaptive capacity. Men and women are also likely to have very different perceptions of climate change and climate risk, and very different approaches to adaptation. But there is very little data or analysis of gender differences in climate change impacts or ability to engage in climate-smart agriculture. Improved information on these issues is needed to design gender-sensitive and pro-poor climate change research approaches that will benefit women and men.

activity.title: Assessing the impact of appropriate risk management financial packages on householdÂ¹s asset portfolios in Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Uruguay
activity.description:
Index insurance is an innovative financial product that helps rural households manage large covariate shocks to agricultural income. Current research is increasingly showing that an effective risk management strategy in the face of climate change will require a combination of indexed insurance, savings and credit and that the correct combination of these three financial products will likely depend on the nature of climatic shocks and rural financial markets
If rural communities have access to such risk management tools they can increase the degree to which they are able to withstand climate risks. The ultimate effect of insurance on the resilience of rural households is thus an empirical question that is likely to vary depending on the situation being considered. However one key difficulty to collect empirical data is that index insurance is a new product, that requires training and proper information and that is subject to basis risk. Therefore in order to collect relevant information and study the impact of actual purchase of index insurance these issues need to be address.
