activity.title: Building climate smart farming systems in Rakai (Uganda)
activity.description: ILRI and IITA are currently jointly organizing the CCAFS farming systems survey in Rakai where coffee/banana systems are dominant. This project will use participatory approaches with farmers, local extension and governance actors, and NGOs to discuss the constraints and opportunities of the coffee/banana system. The focus will be on climate change and adaptation and mitigation strategies that improve farmerâ€™s livelihoods and increase system resilience. Different qualitative approaches will be used to organize knowledge exchange between research and farmer communities and support services. A strongly quantitative approach will be linked to this work to map plot, household, and community level resource flows. This will be used to analyse trade-offs at farm and community / landscape level. Taking into consideration farmersâ€™ preferences and resource limitations, a series of promising scenarios will be developed and discussed.

activity.title: Gender inequality: A barrier to climate adaptation behavior?
activity.description: The study will examine how gender inequality influences household adaptation decisions in Bangladesh, through shaping women's and men's perceptions of risk and their capacities to adapt. The adaptation decision in question is whether or not to invest in cage culture of fish, a new activity introduced to offer an opportunity to diversify livelihood systems. However, investing in the activity itself brings risks that may bar some farm households from investing and gaining the expected benefits. The research will explore how gender norms, attitudes and practices influence the way women and men assess the cage culture opportunity in terms of ots risks and their capacities to adapt, and whether and how these gendered assesments create barriers to households being able or willing to take up and sustain the activity.

activity.title: Further development and improvement of the Analogue tool and linkage with other CCAFS platforms
activity.description: CCAFS has recently developed the "cliamte analogue tool". Based on R language, this tool allows to identify spatial and temporal analog sites that have statistically similar climates based on multiple climate projections. An online portal has also been develop during the first development phase but further methodological validations and improvements need to be done based also in the implementation of the Pilot Farms of the future program (farmer to farmer exchanges) in 2012.

activity.title: Best bets for climate-smart agriculture: The scientific basis
activity.description: Everywhere you turn it seems someone is talking about climate-smart agriculture (CSA). Development practitioners and the popular press are drunk on the idea, policy makers take a more sobering perspective, and scientists seem puzzled, skeptical, and concerned. Despite the mixed emotions, CSA has quickly been integrated into the global development agenda. There is an urgent need to examine CSA objectivity to understand what is really known about purported CSA practices and technologies, the synergies and tradeoffs among its 3-pillars, and socio-ecological niches where CSA is or is not appropriate to calibrate expectations and inform discourse. This project aims to assess the scientific basis for CSA. That is, separate what is well-established from what is more uncertain about proposed CSA practices. Specific focus will be on cataloging CSA being examined under the CGIAR but scope will be expanded as time and resources permit.

activity.title: Managing climate related risks to improve livelihood resilience and adaptive capacity in agricultural ecosystems in Southern Mozambique
activity.description: Within the Government of Mozambique there is a strong interest in, and a growing commitment to climate change issues. At the national level, the government is leading efforts to raise the topic of climate change on the development agenda. Mozambique is particularly vulnerable to climate change due to its geographic location at the confluence of many international rivers flowing into the Indian Ocean; its land area that is below sea level; high vulnerability to cyclones and storms; high temperatures; aridity; infertile soils; lack of communications infrastructure; a high level of illiteracy; high population growth rate; absolute poverty and a high dependence on natural resources that require predictable rain. In the next twenty years Mozambique is predicted to lose 25 per cent of its agricultural productive capacity. These changes will negatively affect crop yields resulting in price increases for basic staples, which can have a serious effect on health and increasing child malnutrition. Systems need to be put into place to manage the risks from such weather and climate variability. The ability to smooth gains and losses due to climate variability requires improved climate information and an institutional framework in which the public and private sector can act quickly and efficiently when provided reliable information.

activity.title: A methodological development of an online tool for the identification of Target Population Environments: improving the predictions of agricultural production using crop models
activity.description: The expected increases in temperature and shifts in precipitation regimes are predicted to cause significant changes in crop productivity across the globe, through direct abiotic influence or through associated changes in pest and disease pressure. While significant adaptive capacity exists within agricultural and socio-economic systems, models suggest that the germplasm that currently underpins production is likely to be â€˜out-reachedâ€™ in some places by change. Hence, crop improvement through conventional breeding or through biotechnological innovations is hailed as a crucial strategy to ensure long-term maintenance or gain in agricultural productivity. Given the long lead-time between commencement of a breeding program and the release and large-scale adoption of new cultivars in farmersâ€™ fields, it is critical that breeding programs are initiated today to address future problems. It is therefore key that priorities are developed for crop improvement programs based on sound ex-ante analysis of future benefits, and that coherent strategies across multiple countries and between institutions are adopted and implemented. International and national donor and government policies should be coordinated in enabling the conception and implementation of these strategies.

activity.title: Adaptation strategies for crops to climate change (CIRAD)
activity.description: This project serves to develop adaptation strategies for crops to climate change, based on crop improvement through breeding. A crop modeling approach using present and future climate scenarios is to be implemented. Once appropriate crop models have been improved and calibrated/validated, they will be used to (1) measure the impact of climate change scenarios on existing crop varieties, and (2) determine trait combinations (ideotype concepts) that would improve adaptation and performance. A more simple and general, multi-crop, spatialized approach will be implemented by the University of Leeds, whereas detailed zoom-ins will be performed for rice and sorghum by CIRAD and its partners.

Developing community-based climate smart agriculture through participatory action research in five benchmark sites in West Africa
activity.description: One of CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) over-arching objectives is to assess and test pro-poor adaptation and mitigation practices, technologies and policies for food systems, adaptive capacity and rural livelihoods. This task will be carried out through an adaptive “placed-based” research structured around three Themes (Adaptation to progressive climate change, Adaptation through risk management and Pro-poor mitigation) aiming to decrease the vulnerability of rural communities and enable them to prosper under a variable and changing climate. A fourth Theme – Integration for Decision Making –will ensure effective engagement with rural communities and institutional and policy stakeholders, grounds it in the policy context, and provide, through a demand-driven process, downscaled analyses and tools for future climates. The question is how to balance crop production while sustaining the diverse ecosystem services provided by agricultural landscapes in response to future climate change? As an example, one of the key mechanisms is the use of sound agroforestry systems by which diverse perennial plant communities can confer greater resilience and stability of key ecosystem functions relative to annual or simplified cropping systems, thereby enhancing overall adaptive capacity to environmental change. It is based on comparative advantage that CCAFS-WA has identifier ICRAF to lead the facilitation process of the participatory action research about climate smart agriculture. The overall methodological approach will capitalize on-going actions and findings of existing projects, act to encourage partners to add missing components to the existing and on-going projects and initiate new activities when deemed appropriate. More specifically, this PAR work will use the climate smart village model approach (see figure below) to implement the various projects and activities that will be defined through participatory identification of gaps and research priorities in each country/site. This will be mainly led by the multi-disciplinary teams that will be formed in each country to conduct the work. The work should where possible, build on existing projects and be located at CCAFS benchmark sites. Priority countries sites are Cinzana (Ségou region, Mali), Lawra (Lawra-Jirapa region, Ghana), Tougou (Yatenga region, Burkina Faso), Fakara (Kollo region, Niger) and Kaffrine (Kaffrine region, Senegal). Other projects/initiatives in other countries in the sub-region could be considered if strongly relevant. In view of the specificity of certain components of the work, ICRAF will have to liaise with identified partners (e.g. components on climate services and weather insurance will be separately covered through AGRHYMET) to incorporate their outputs in the climate smart village work. A range of options will be tested across a range of soil, climatic and socio-economic conditions, and their adoption, adaptation and performance will be assessed. They should be integrative of the climate smart village components described below and will be identified by the country multi-disciplinary teams using a participatory approach during the first workshop.
